FacilityName: Alta-Dena Certified Dairy, LLC - Buena Park

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Ice Cream and Frozen Dessert Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
DESCRIPTION OF FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED:

Dean Foods of California, LLC of Buena Park, CA produces ice cream and frozen desserts.  The facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as refrigerant to freeze ice cream and to maintain the proper temperature of ice cream and frozen desserts within the facility.  Anhydrous ammonia is an effective and environmentally friendly refrigerant that has been used for many years by most food processing facilities.  The refrigerant would be a gas at ambient temperatures, but is handled as a gas liquefied under pressure in a closed loop refrigeration system.  The refrigeration system consists of a high-pressure receiver, recirculators, condensers, evaporators, compressors, piping, and valves.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

As a part of its PMS Program, Dean Foods utilizes all the Elements of the PSM/RMP/CalARP requirements which are helpful in maintaining our system in very good condition and preventing accidental releases of ammonia.  These Elements included:

     Process Safety Information
     Process Hazard Analysis
     Operation Procedures
     Training
     Mechanical Integrity
     Management of Changd
     Pre-Startup Review
     Compliance Audits
     Incident Investigations
     Employee Participation
     Hot Work Permits
     Contractor Safety

EMERGENCY RESPONSE INFORMATION:

As a part of the PSM Program, the facility maintains an Emergency Action Plan that was prepared in order to improve responsiveness to an emergency incident, and to increase the realibility of actions taken during an incident.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies as well as the public.

In the event of an emergency involving the refrigeration system, it is the policy of the facility to request assistance as necessary by calling 911, which will notify the California Region

1 LEPC.  In addition, the LEPC has included Dean Foods in its local emergency response planning.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDSENT HISTORY:

The facility has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due in part to our stringent release prevention programs, there have been no accidental release during this period.

STEPS TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

The facility works very closely with the Orange County Fire Authority in all Elements of the program.  OCFA participates in our Process Hazard Analyses, Management of Change, Pre-startup safety reviews, Compliance Audits and Mechanical Integrity.  We feel our working with the OCFA is very important and assures that we maintain our Program at the highest standards.  Since the last PHA resubmission, additional sensors have been installed.  Employee training and operating procedure reviews are emphasized as part of continuous improvement goals at our facility.  The facility will continue to operate and maintain the refrigeration system in accordance with industry association standards and will continue operate under the PSM/RMP/CalARP Program requirements.

EXTERNAL EVENTS ANALYSES:

Under CalARP program requirements, applicable external events are considered within the hazard review.  Hazard reviews are encompassed within a complete Process Safety Management program, which is reviewed and updated every five years.  Such events included, but were not limited to; seismic activity & sabotage with the effect on safety of the facility and the surroundings being considered.

SABOTAGE

The Dean Foods facility is located on a site controlled by security officers, operating 24 hours per day, 7 days per week.  These officers provide active, secured restricted access with manual inspections and verification of all vehicles entering and leaving the property.  Additionally, a secondary level of restricted access exists within the production facility.  A key code entry is required to gain access to the production facil

ity and refrigeration room.  For these reasons, the likelihood of a chemical accident was considered remote.

SEISMIC ACTIVITY

The potential for earthquakes, and the possible effect on the facility were taken into account.  The existing seismic restraints incorporated into the facility/equipment design were also considered.  In the event of a loss of pressure in the refrigeration system due to a system breach, the system would be automatically shut down via pressure sensing controls and/or ammonia sensors.  Because of inherent safety controls within the refrigeration system, a chemical release under this scenario was considered an "alternate release", although not as likely to occur as others considered.

FIRE / EXPLOSION

An emergency ventilation system is in place which would operate automatically to maintain the concentration of ammonia in the Engine Room at no more than 25% of the  lower explosive level.  Obviously, the possibility of an explosion and/or fire related to the facility refrigeration system was considered, although the occurrence would be very remote.  In such an event, the refrigeration (ignition) source would be removed by shutting down the feed valves and appropriate safety measures would be taken by operation personnel.  If a fire is of an electrical nature, power to the affected area would be shut down via circuit breakers.

WEATHER

Various weather conditions, and their possible effect on the facilities refrigeration system were also studied, and considered to be remote.
